text:
Pipeline is everything. It's easy to hold off on sales/prospecting when you're feeling 'comfortable' with your income/activity levels, but no matter how good your work is, client needs change over time and good clients may end up cancelling, bringing things in-house, etc. Even if it's some lightweight cold emailing or staying active in FB groups where your customers hang out, it'll pay off.

Try to avoid getting all your income from one or two clients - even if they pay you well. If they cancel or don't need more work, you'll suddenly lose pretty much all of your income. The more clients you have (even if they're on smaller retainers), the more you spread the risk.

Also, Laura's points above are great - schedule time off!

Also, Laura's points above are great - schedule time off!

text:
Hi all, I recently got internally promoted from an entry-level Content Writer to a Creative Comms Manager. My day-to-day consists a lot of the same, but with more strategic thinking and autonomy (I can just run with my ideas instead of asking for permission). I only have a few years of experience under my belt, and was promoted to a position that asked for more experience than I actually have. My team is behind me and wants me to succeed in the role. I don't have the responsibility of managing people now, but the expectation is I will in the future. So I'm asking this group for advice:
1. What frameworks or nuggets of advice do you have for someone who is taking on a more managerial role?
2. What helped you during a transitional period where you were ramping up into a bigger role?
3. How have you overcome /dealt with the -- "They don't have enough experience" bias that a lot of less experienced managers face?
Thank you for any thoughts / stray comments / recommendations you have in advance!

elements.text: Hi all, I recently got internally promoted from an entry-level Content Writer to a Creative Comms Manager. I don't have the responsibility of managing people now, but the expectation is I will in the future. So I'm asking this group for advice:
What frameworks or nuggets of advice do you have for someone who is taking on a more managerial role?
What helped you during a transitional period where you were ramping up into a bigger role?
How have you overcome /dealt with the -- "They don't have enough experience" bias that a lot of less experienced managers face?
Thank you for any thoughts / stray comments / recommendations you have in advance!

text:
Hey Anna- congrats on the new role! I did a similar shift a few years back, though I'm more on the demand generation side of things than content so YMMV.

I found the most difficult part for me was thinking about projects and ideas on a longer scale than was done previously. When you are an entry-level hire or a junior employee, you aren't really expected to plan much farther ahead than your day or week, but once you are managing folks/strategy, you will need to think at a monthly, quarterly or even yearly scale of what you want to achieve.

On starting a new role at a new company, I like to put together a 30-60-90 day plan - it might be a good tool for you in starting this new role as well. You can add in projects to be finished (e.g. write a long-form case study), plans to be made (design quarterly content calendar and process, set KPIs for next year), as well as personal goals (learn a new tool, find a mentor). You can show your plan to your boss/teammates and also get feedback from them to see whether or not your expectations for the role are aligned with theirs, and demonstrate that you are taking your new responsibility seriously!

I imagine they promoted you because you are showing a lot of promise in your ideas and quality of work, so the "level up" needed to move to a managerial role is usually around communication, planning, and ownership. Good luck, hopefully this is helpful! :relaxed:

text:
Toughest thing is realizing you can’t write everything and are now an air traffic controller. You have to give up some control of that to be forward thinking and strategic for your team vs. in the weeds. Truly my biggest struggle still, but something I’d flag. If you’re spending more time writing or editing than coaching, planning, etc…it’s a flag that you may need to reprioritize.

Congratulations and good luck in your new role! :tada:

Congratulations and good luck in your new role!

text: Thank you <@U01DHUL21J9> !! I think you're exactly right - planning projects in a bubble that last a few weeks is one thing, but thinking bigger and longer is a new challenge. I love the idea of systematizing a calendar for planning that includes several layers of projects, goals, etc. I will definitely be trying it out! Thank you, it is much appreciated!

!! I think you're exactly right - planning projects in a bubble that last a few weeks is one thing, but thinking bigger and longer is a new challenge. text: <@U01694YQ3FX> I think in my head, it was about finding a balance between the two, but that's not it is it. There's definitely still a mindset shift about the 'work' I'm still working through. Thank you!!

text:
I echo everyone else here. I’ve been a new manager of a new department for the past year after being in an individual contributor role (which sometimes I miss).

Two things I routinely read to keep me oriented as a manager, which apply to any manager role, I recommend:

This twitter thread: <https://twitter.com/brosandprose/status/1202762015095377920>

And The Bent newsletter, about being a better manager: <https://thebent.co/>

text: <@U013K9AEHR7> depends on team size and expectations for output. Maybe you do still have time to write/create—but it gets tough to find as people want more and the team grows and you have all the new fun admin tasks as a manager/strategist to do :upside_down_face:. Even when I was in more junior roles, I still outsource a lot of writing to get it all done, so I’ve always felt more like an editor/air traffic controller (again depending on budgets, volume, etc.)

text:
The thing I'd suggest then (though this is admittedly based on a lot of years of experience in the app dev world, from which I came) is to think of problem solving in four phases:
1. Diagnosis of the problem
2. Prescription of a therapy
3. Application of a therapy
4. Re-application of a therapy
Consultants do (1) and (2).  Contractors do (3) and (4).  Selling (3) and (4) and then trying to convince clients who pay you for those things to listen to you about (1) and (2) is insanely difficult (like a handyman you hire to fix a cabinet trying to convince you to let him design your new construction for your next house).  So I'd market and sell (1) and (2) exclusively, and quietly do (3) and (4) just to pay the bills, until you don't need to anymore

text: In the world of content strategy, I'd say this means selling content strategies and roadmaps, for instance, and offering to refer or subcontract the work if a client asks, "could you also write the landing pages and SEO optimization, while you're at it?"

text: To <@UUJBMDVGB>’s point, it's also easier to avoid whale clients and have a well-distributed book of business when you sell strategy or productized consulting and subcontract.  Executing/laboring tends to fill your days, which tends to mean a pretty low ceiling on concurrent clients.

’s point, it's also easier to avoid whale clients and have a well-distributed book of business when you sell strategy or productized consulting and subcontract.  Executing/laboring tends to fill your days, which tends to mean a pretty low ceiling on concurrent clients.

text:
Anyone have some advice on how to give negative feedback to a manager?

I believe he thinks we're actual friends. In reality I detest having him as a manager.

I think there is still opportunity for me at the company, but I'm actively looking at opportunities to get away from him.

I believe he does want to help me advance my career, but I don't know how to begin the conversation of why he is a bad manager for _me._

Do I suck it up, find something better or try to get through to him?

me.

text: What do you detest about his management?

elements.text: What do you detest about his management?

text:
I don't think it makes sense for me to even be on his team, and I don't think I'm a good fit at all.

The frustrating thing is I have a mentor, who is a team manager, we get along great, and I think I am a good fit for his team.

But I got transferred to this other team instead :man-shrugging:
